data.title: Sri Lanka Wildlife Tour: The Complete Guide
data.short_description: Planning a wildlife tour in Sri Lanka? Sri Lanka, an island surrounded by the beautiful blue waters, is situated in the Indian Ocean, giving easy access from any country across the world.

content.content:
Planning a wildlife tour in Sri Lanka? [Sri Lanka](https://www.olankatravels.com/tour-packages/sri-lanka-tours), an island surrounded by the beautiful blue waters, is situated in the Indian Ocean, giving easy access from any country across the world. This tropical country is blessed with a wonderful climate ranging from the warm suburbs to the cold hill country, a gorgeous coast and a beach line surrounding the country, a treasured wildlife and endangered animals, a history that can be traced back to hundreds of years and many more. Thus, it is one of the most celebrated tourist destinations amongst the travellers all around the world.

## Truly the Wonder of Asia, don't you think?

Sri Lanka, a gem of an island, beckons travellers not just for its scenic splendour but also for its vibrant wildlife. Here, amid the lush landscapes, one can encounter a host of endangered species flourishing in their native ecosystems. For those eager to immerse themselves in the thrilling spectacle of Sri Lankas natural world, our team is ready to guide you through a selection of wildlife tours tailored to fit both your desires and your budget. 

With a plethora of options available upon your arrival, from adrenaline-fueled safaris to serene camping by cascading waterfalls, your Sri Lankan wildlife adventure awaits. Consider this a morsel of inspiration: the national parks of this resplendent isle are sanctuaries where the wild resides, offering encounters with nature in its purest form. Let us help you discover these treasures, where each visit contributes to the preservation and appreciation of a world teeming with wonders.

## Sri Lanka Wildlife Tours Locations

- Yala
- Udawalawe
- Wilpattu
- Kumana
- Wasgamuwa
- Minneriya
- [Bundala](https://www.olankatravels.com/blog/bundala-national-park/) 
- Horton Plains
- Gal Oya
- Lunugamvehera
- Kaudulla
- Sinharaja
- Knuckles
- Kithulgala
- Kanneliya

## Yala National Park

![sri-lanka-wildlife-tour-packages.webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/sri_lanka_wildlife_tour_packages_9100217bb2.webp)

This is a must in your wildlife holidays in Sri Lanka. [Yala National Park](https://www.yalasrilanka.lk/) consists of six national parks and three wildlife sanctuaries and is situated in the city of Hambantota, which is only 260 km to the South East of [Colombo](https://www.olankatravels.com/blog/colombo-travel-guide/).

Yala is renowned as the most visited national park of the country given its geographical location, the climate and above all the dense leopard population.

You can hop on a jeep and have a safari ride in and about the forest, this will give you an unforgettable experience and a look through the natural lifestyle of the wild animals such as the majestic Elephant, the elusive Sri Lankan Leopard, the always chattering monkeys, and bear, and also hundreds of different species of birds, reptiles, butterflies and many more.

## Udawalawa

![sri-lanka-wildlife-tour.webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/sri_lanka_wildlife_tour_b16ac1f480.webp)

The Udawalawa National Park is situated in the Uva Province in the city of Monaragala which is only a five hour drive from Colombo.

The majestic Elephant plays a major role in the wildlife of Sri Lanka. They can be easily sighted unlike the other wild animals given the high population. Thus if you are an elephant enthusiast and are looking for a place to have a wildlife experience udawalawa National park is the ideal.

Apart from the herd of wild elephants you can also witness wild boars, buffalos, deer, and many other endangered and unique species of wild animals such as black naped hare, endemic Toque Macaque and Gray langurs.

Moreover the Sri Lanka Wildlife Holidays offer you the opportunity to enjoy wildlife camping schemes to meet your budget and the time that you can spend on your vacation.

## Wilpattu

![sri-lanka-wildlife-holidays.webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/sri_lanka_wildlife_holidays_b7e23d6947.webp)

This is situated about four hours away from Colombo in the City of Puttalam about 30 km west to [Anuradhapura](https://www.olankatravels.com/blog/anuradhapura-travel-guide/), and is considered as the most beautiful national park of the country. So dont forget to visit this beautiful park while you are on your Wildlife Tour in Sri Lanka.

The best time to visit wilpattu would be in October, and while you are on your safari ride you will be able to witness the famous Sri Lankan wildlife such as the Elephant, the Leopard, the sloth bear and the deer. Moreover will also be able to witness endangered species of birds, plants and flowers.

## Kumana

![wildlife-tour-packages-in-sri-lanka.webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/wildlife_tour_packages_in_sri_lanka_966131b335.webp)

This is situated in the Eastern part of the Wilpattu National Park, and is mostly famous for being the home for a large number of endangered bird species and also migrant birds, especially the waterfowl and the wading birds. These birds nest during the month of May in the bushes of mangroves and in the month of June the new birds are born.

The park is bounded on the South by the Kumbukkan Oya where the main camping site for bird watching is situated. There are Wildlife tour packages so as to provide you with vintage and yet luxurious stay while camping.

Contact [Olanka Travels](https://www.olankatravels.com/) to arrange Sri Lanka wildlife tour packages.

data.title: Batticaloa Travel Guide: The Complete Guide
data.short_description: Batticaloa, or simply Batti, is a historic city in Sri Lanka. The city is surrounded by marvelous lagoons and palm trees.

content.content: Batticaloa, or simply Batti, is a historic city in Sri Lanka. The city is surrounded by marvelous lagoons and palm trees. People called this city the land of the singing fish. Batticaloa, the former capital of Sri Lanka, is located in the east coast region, which is 69 miles south-east of Trincomalee. The entire city is a small city with a smaller population. You can easily explore the city while walking. This city is steeped in beautiful sandy beaches, lagoons, and historical architecture from the Dutch Empire.

## Things to see in Batticaloa

**Passikudah Bay:** Passikudah Bay is the top attraction of Batticaloa, which contains a thin set of coral reefs heading towards the outside bay with sprinkled coral communities inside the bay. This place is linked with the similar reef systems that are further south to the Kalkudah. This reef system is one of the best systems in the eastern region. It was proposed as a Marine Sanctuary by NARA. Passikudah is famous for its calm water, and it is located 28 km north of Batticaloa district of the Eastern Province.

**Batticaloa Fort:** This fort was a Portuguese settlement and it was first created in 1628 as a trading and administrative centre. Built on a small island, Batticaloa fort extends beyond into a swampy lagoon, which surveys the salty waters (these salty waters are protected by the cities outside banks). This fort is a magnificent remnant of the Dutch colonial prowess, and it was used for various trade activities. However, the King Rajasinghe of Kandy had other ideas, and he resigned to agree with the Dutch rulers. Later in 1638, he claimed this fort and made this area sovereign from the Dutch rulers.


## Things to do in Batticaloa

**Visiting the beaches:** Batticaloa is a famous city in Sri Lanka. It has some of the best sandy beaches in the entire Sri Lanka, such as  Pasikuda and Kalkuda. These beaches are extremely beautiful with shallow waters. Apart from these beaches, there are also other beaches that draw many tourists from around the world. These beaches include  Nasivanthivu beach in Vaharai, Palchenai beach, Mankeni beach, etc. All these beaches are ideal for gathering and people will enjoy the soothing sceneries along the beaches as well. Also, the sunrise and sunset sceneries in these beaches will leave the tourists in wonder as both of these times will present something unique to behold.

**Go for a boat ride:** Batticaloa has several boat spots in which you can go for a boat ride. Training guides will guide you with safe equipment. Remember that boat rides become more exciting because of the lagoons in Batticaloa. Within these lagoons, there are a few tiny islands that are perfect for bird watching and camping.

**Explore the Coconut Cultural Park:**  Coconut cultural park is close to the Passikudah beach, sitting in front of the malu malu resort inside the coconut cultivation firm. There are lots of things to do in this park like  a ride on the bull by a cart, discovering the handicraft preparation process, and local food making process. Plus, you would love to have coconut ice cream and see the cultural dance in the park.

**Bird Watching:** Batticaloa is famous for inimitable species of birds as the lagoons in Batticaloa offer you opportunities to see these exciting birds. Generally, the main lagoon extends to more than 50 km and the best island for bird watching is the Bone Island (Which can be reached by boat from the Batti Lagoon Park and Batticaloas Lighthouse area). Besides, Batticaloas Buffalo Island and Manthivu Island offers you the chance to see the migrating birds and if you go to the eco-park in Palameenmadu, you will see a tower. From that tower, you can see lots of birds and this is why this tower is famous in Batticaloa for bird viewing.

## How is the weather in Batticaloa?

Batticaloa has two different seasons  Tropical wet and dry climate. Generally, the climate of this city is warm all year round, with a few variations. Amazingly, the season in Batticaloa is marked by the rains instead of temperature. The monsoon season is long here, and it lasts from November to March. This season is considered to be the low season for tourists. Now, the best time to visit Batticaloa is April to September, which is either side of the monsoon season. At this time, the weather is dry but doesnt get too warm and hot.

## How to reach Batticaloa?

You can reach Batticaloa by the following transportation 

**By Car:** You can reach Batticaloa by private car, and you can also hire cars from car rental companies.

**By Train:** In between Colombo and Batticaloa route, the trains reach and depart on a regular basis. Usually, this journey will take eight to nine hours.

- From Colombo to Batticaloa: The morning train departs at 6:10 AM and the night train leaves at 7:15 PM.
- From Batticaloa to Colombo: The morning train leaves at 7:15 AM and the night train will depart at 8:15 PM.

To get on the trains, you have to bring the tickets from the station directly. There is also an option for advance booking from the station.

**By Bus:** To reach Batticaloa, you can also opt for public buses. Following table will help you to know the time of departure of public buses and duration of travel from different cities to Batticaloa.

Finally, Batticaloa is standing on a small island, but it represents far more than this tiny island because when you stroll on the beaches or go for a boat ride on the lagoons, you will realise that this place is close to heaven. So, enjoy your stay at Batticaloa and bath in the beauties of this magnificent place with our Batticaloa travel guide.

For inquiries, contact [Olanka Travels](link). Check out our [Sri Lanka 7-day itinerary](link) to include Batticaloa.

data.title: Sri Lanka Ramayana Tour: The Complete Guide
data.short_description: The Ramayana is a landmark story in the History of both [Sri Lanka](link) and our neighbor India, and this story has been interpreted by the writers of both the countries to embrace their own hero.

content.content:
# The Complete Guide On Sri Lanka Ramayana Tour

The Ramayana is a landmark story in the History of both [Sri Lanka](https://www.olankatravels.com/tour-packages/sri-lanka-tours) and our neighbor India, and this story has been interpreted by the writers of both the countries to embrace their own hero. However, this article will give you an outline as to the Ramayana related places to visit that hold a tourist value; the Sri Lanka Ramayana Tour.

Sri Lanka is a country of not just beautiful places to visit, but also a country of a valued history and a treasured heritage, the Ramayana trail is one of the best examples of that.

The story of Ramayana is cherished especially among the Hindu devotees, thus this tour of Ramayana will give a spiritual travel experience to the Hindus. Moreover, this tour experience would give the Non-Hindu travellers an immense knowledge as to the rich Sri Lankan heritage.

This article will speak about a few Sri Lanka Ramayana Sites you could visit while on your holiday. These exciting places have been said to have touched with the Sri Lanka Ramayana trail, so dont forget to read the Ramayana story before you embark upon the excursion. Thus, once you have read the story you will be more curious as to find about the trails, and you will be able to witness the places, the scenarios of this story actually took place while you are on your Sri Lanka Ramayana Tour Itinerary.

Witnessing these sites and hearing the stories entangled with the Ramayana Legacy will prove that these things have actually happened in the past and are not merely restricted to the history books.

There are about forty major and minor sites that will leave you believing in faith if you are a Hindu devotee, while it will leave any other traveler quite mesmerized by the breathtaking views. Moreover, for the ones who are researching the history this tours will be of an educational value.

So here is a list of Ramayana sites in Sri Lanka.

## Muneeswaran Temple

![Munnesswaram (1).webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/Munnesswaram_1_e4301eeca4.webp)

This temple situated in Chilaw is one of the oldest Hindu temples in Sri Lanka and one of must-see Ramayana places in Sri Lanka that claims to have connections with the heritage of Ramayana. The Legend says that this was the place where Lord Rama prayed for God Shiva after he had defeated King Ravana who was a Brahmin. Killing a Brahmin or Brahmicide was considered as the greatest crime according to the Hindus, and when Lord Rama prayed for a remedy after killing King Ravana he preached that the only remedy would be to install five lingams (a symbol of divine generative energy as a symbol of Shiva).

## Manavari Sivan Kovil

This Kovil or the Hindu temple is situated about 10 kilometres above Chilaw, in the Puttalam District, North Western Province of Ceylon.

When Lord Rama killed the King Ravanam, God Shiva advised him to erect five lingams in Sri Lanka, to rectify the Brahmicide he committed by virtue of killing Ravana. This Manavari kovil holds the first Lingam installed by Lord Rama (Ramalingam). So this is one of the most important Ramayana related places in Sri Lanka.

## Rumassala

During the battle, King Ravana and his brother were both critically injured and Hanuman was sent to the Himalayan in India to bring a lifesaving herb. Given the fact that Hanuman had forgotten the name of the herb by the time he went to Himalayan, he uprooted a part of the forest and brought it to Lanka.

Rumassala is considered as one of the five places where Hanuman has dropped fragments of this mountain as it slipped from his hands while bringing it to Ravana. The other places are; Dolu kanda in Kurunegala, Ritigala in Anuradhapura Road, Thalladi in Mannar and Kachchativu in the North.

## Ram Sethu

This is also known as the Adams Bridge, which is situated at Talaimannar the top most point of Sri Lanka which is also the closest point to India. The history tells that when Lord Rama got to know Princess Seetha was kept in captive in Ceylon, he with the help of hanuman and his army built this bridge using stones (corals) with his name on it and these corals can be seen if you visit the Panchamukhi Hanuman temple in Rameshwaram.

## Ravana Cave and Temple

![Ravana-Cave.jpg](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/Ravana_Cave_ff04e3fc11.jpg)

This is situated about 2 kilometres from Ella. If you observe the rocks and the caves patiently, you will see that these are not natural caves but man made ones, thus showing the architectural intelligence of King Ravana. The cave has openings to several larger caves which end after about 10 feet to the inside and one smaller cave which seems to have no end at all, and it is said to believe that this cave leads to various parts of the country. The reason behind making the caves would have been to travel within the country without drawing much attention.

Among the aforesaid Ramayana sites in Sri Lanka, here is a list of other sites of Sri Lanka Ramayana trail that you could visit while on your holiday.

1. Thiruketheeswaram temple  Mannar
2. Koneswaram Kovil  Trincomalee
3. Sigiriya  [Dambulla](https://www.olankatravels.com/blog/dambulla-travel-guide/)
4. Bhakta Hanuman Temple  Ramboda (on the route to Nuwara Eliya)
5. Ashoka Vatika  Nuwara Eliya
6. Seeta Amman Temple  Badulla (opposite the Hakgala Botanical Gardens)
7. Seetha Kotuwa  Hasalaka
8. Pulasthi Statue  Polonnaruwa
9. Ramboda Falls  Nuwara Eliya
10. The Chariot Path  on the top of the Ramboda Hills [(Kandy-Gampola-Nuwara Eliya](https://www.olankatravels.com/blog/kandy-travel-guide/) Road)

So Contact [Olanka Travels](https://www.olankatravels.com/) to arrange Ramayana tours in Sri Lanka.

data.title: Kandy Travel Guide: The Complete Guide
data.short_description: Kandy is considered as a chief tourist destination of Sri Lanka. The city of Kandy is the second-largest city after Colombo, and it is also regarded as the cultural capital of Sri Lanka. Whats more, Kandy is nestled in the hills at an altitude of 488 meters, and it is situated 115 km away from Colombo.

content.content: Kandy is considered as a chief tourist destination of Sri Lanka. The city of Kandy is the second-largest city after [Colombo](https://www.olankatravels.com/blog/colombo-travel-guide/), and it is also regarded as the cultural capital of Sri Lanka. Whats more, Kandy is nestled in the hills at an altitude of 488 meters, and it is situated 115 km away from Colombo. Besides, the city lies in the middle of hills in the Kandy plateau and the city is both an administrative and religious city in the Central Province of Sri Lanka. Interestingly, the name of this city was given from the word Kanda (means a hill) in Sinhala by the colonial rulers.

## Things to see in Kandy

**The Temple of the Tooth:** The temple of the tooth is one of the most significant attractions of Kandy. This temple is also the most-valued Buddhist place of worship in the entire Sri Lanka. The major attraction of the temple is the Buddhas teeth, which were kept in the temple. Usually, the temple is open from dawn to dusk, and it was built in the 16th century. You have to wear a certain dress to enter the temple. There is a set of rituals that are performed daily. All in all, this temple is one of the sacred shrines of Sri Lanka.

**Old Royal Palace Compound:** Old Royal Palace Compound is by far the most striking tourist attraction in Kandy. You will enjoy a lot while taking tours to the quarters of the royal concubines, old royal palace, queens chambers, the council chambers, and the armoury. In order to represent the Kandyan era, almost all the places are used as museums. Also, these places represent several historical events of the Kandyan era.

**The Royal Botanical Garden in Peradeniya:** The Royal Botanical Garden in Peradeniya is the best botanical garden in Kandy and the most visited botanical garden in Sri Lanka. The ancient kings of Sri Lanka had made this botanical garden, but the British have refurbished the look of the garden as well. They used the garden to grow trees that were not possible to grow in Great Britain. This botanical garden consists of a big banyan tree, an orchid house, and the suspension bridge.

**The Spice Garden:** Kandy is renowned for lots of spice gardens. You will see different spices and plants such as  cinnamon, alo-evera, etc. In short, the spice gardens are quite interesting and you will definitely enjoy watching them.

## Things to do in Kandy

**Ride on an Elephant:** The Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage offers you something different. Here, you can feed and ride on the elephants. Also, you can enjoy the sights of an elephant shower while getting up close to them. Above all, visiting this elephant orphanage is a must-do activity in Kandy.

**Visit the Big Buddha:** Visiting the Big Buddha on top of the hill beats everything in Kandy. This Big Buddha is a part of the small temple complex. What you will most enjoy is the view of Kandy from the top. The city, the mountain ranges in the background, the lake; you can see everything from the top. So, you cant simply miss the Big Buddha.

**Explore a Tea Garden:** Sri Lanka is the number one country for producing a large amount of tea in the world, and Kandy houses many renowned tea gardens. So, taking a tour to explore a tea garden would provide you some amazing sights like tea workers plucking tea plants, the beautiful smell of raw teas, and many more natural sights.

**Do some shopping in the Kandy City Center:** This city centre in Kandy is a 10-storied complex. After 12 years of construction, the city centre was opened in 2005. Now, you can do some shopping in this city centre since the complex offers a wide variety of shopping options. Plus, this city centre is the only shopping complex in the entire city of Kandy.

Also read our guide on [best hotels in Kandy](https://www.olankatravels.com/hotels-in-kandy/) to select the best accommodation in Kandy.

## How is the weather in Kandy?

The weather of Kandy is cooler and wetter than the usual tropical weather of Sri Lanka. Generally, Kandy has two different seasons  the monsoon season and the dry season. In Kandy, the driest months are December to April and the average temperature is between 22C and 30C. On the other hand, the monsoon season in Kandy starts from May and lasts until August. In the monsoon season, the average temperature ranges from 25C to 29C. Finally, the humidity of Kandy lies in between 70% and 79%.

## How to reach Kandy?

In order to reach Kandy, you can take the following options 

**By Bus:** Bus is the best option to reach Kandy. From the Bandaranaike International Airport, you can take the free shuttle bus to reach the bus terminal. From the terminal, you can take the local bus to reach Kandy. The estimated journey time will be around three hours. Also, you can reach Kandy from Colombo by getting on the public buses.

**By Train:** Travelling by train is the cheapest option, and using the trains to reach Kandy would be far easier. With that said, intercity express trains are trouble-free and scenic. You have to book your reservation in advance. The entire trip from Colombo to Kandy would cost you LKR220 in second class and the first class would cost LKR750.

**By Taxi:** Travelling a taxi represents a comfortable journey to Kandy, but it will be expensive as well. You can hire a taxi from the Colombo airport terminal for around LKR 6,000. The estimated duration of the journey is approximately three hours.

Finally, Kandy is one of the prominent cities of Sri Lanka that symbolises the culture of the country. It is a city with diverse elements and sights. Also, this is why people from around the world flock in numbers to visit this city. So, pack your bags today and hop over a travel trip to Kandy with our Kandy travel guide!

For inquiries, contact [Olanka Travels](https://www.olankatravels.com/). Select our [Sri Lanka 1 month itinerary](https://www.olankatravels.com/sri-lanka-itinerary-4-weeks/) where Kandy has included.

data.title: Sri Lankan Cultural Dance: A Brief insight
data.short_description: Sri Lanka is called the Wonder of Asia. It boasts some of the best travel places in the world, with some mesmerising natural beauties. It also has a rich history with a magnificent cultural tradition.

content.content:
Sri Lanka is called the Wonder of Asia. It boasts some of the best travel places in the world, with some mesmerising natural beauties. It also has a rich history with a magnificent cultural tradition. Now, this magnificent cultural tradition wasnt created overnight. In fact, it has a lot of different unique elements like  the language, foods, religious beliefs, dancing, etc. So, we shall have a look at one of its major elements  dancing, to get an idea of why this country is revered by millions of people.

![sri-lankan-cultural-dance.webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/sri_lankan_cultural_dance_9ec059d5d4.webp)

## The History of Sri Lankan Cultural Dance

At first, the people of Sri Lanka mastered the art of dancing to worship the supernatural power. They danced to satisfy the supernatural powers or Gods because they feared them. In the 4th century (B.C.), Sri Lankan people used dancing as a means to expel natural calamities or sickness. However, at the end of Polonnaruwa era (15th century A.D.), people in Sri Lanka were greatly influenced by South Indian dancing cultures. They adopted the arts of South Indian dancing into their folk dancing. By the passing of time, people developed a new dancing style, and it differed from each other in terms of regions or local destinations.

Over the course of time, Sri Lankan people have developed three distinct dancing forms. These are as follows 

- The Kandyan dances of the Up Country
- The Low country dances of the southern plains
- Sabaragamuwa dances (Sabaragamuwa Natum)

## Kandyan Dancing

This style was developed during the reign of Kandyan kings. Right now, Kandyan dancing is the national dance of Sri Lanka. Typically, it impersonates the different movements of animals such as elephants, peacock. Intriguingly, this dance style depicts the iconic scenes of [Ramayana stories](https://www.olankatravels.com/sri-lanka-ramayana-tour). The Kandyan dancers wear remarkable costumes. For example  the male dancers wear skirt-like dresses, in which their chests are decorated with exclusive silver regalia and stunning headgear. They also wear silver bangles on their arms and ankles.

In addition to these striking costumes, the dance performance is matched with hectic rhythms  gata beraya. With that in mind, the Kandyan dance is performed for drumming only, where the most common drum is gata beraya. The dancers are helped to maintain the rhythmic displays by a small pair of cymbals (known as the Thalampota).

## Sabaragamuwa Dances

The Sabaragamuwa dance style is performed to worship the God of Saman. Typically, this dance is exclusively performed in Ratnapura. The local people love and revere the God Saman in a fascinating way. Whats more, this dance style is a combination of both Kandyan Dance and Low country dance. Both male and female dancers are allowed to perform this dance.

## Low Country Dance

This is a highly ritualistic dance in Sri Lanka. Usually, it is performed to mollify the evil spirits. People use this form of dance to expel sickness from their life. The dancers wear masks to depict different characters such as demons, birds, reptiles, etc.

### Conclusion

Sri Lanka is a different country with diverse cultural traditions. It has been the centre of attraction for many years. The above dance styles are just a prime example of why people from all over the world revere this iconic country! So, you better visit Sri Lanka once in your lifetime to experience the Sri Lankan cultural dance.

For inquiries contact [Olanka Travels](https://www.olankatravels.com/).

data.title: Colombo Travel Guide: The Complete Guide
data.short_description: Colombo is the capital city of Sri Lanka, and it is the most popular city as well. The name of the city (Colombo) was first given by the Portuguese in 1505.

content.content:
Colombo is the capital city of Sri Lanka, and it is the most popular city as well. The name of the city (Colombo) was first given by the Portuguese in 1505. The name was derived from the standard Sinhalese name Kolon thota or Kola-amba-thota, which means port on the river Kelani or harbour with leafy mango trees, respectively. The city is located on the west coast of the island, and it is close to Sri Jayawardenepura Kotte, which happens to be the legislative capital of Sri Lanka.

Colombo is a busy city with a cosmopolitan culture. It is the rendezvous point for beaches in the southern region of Sri Lanka. The city boasts a long line of history as a port city that serve the east-west trade routes and at that time the Portuguese, the Dutch, and the British Empire ruled the entire area. In addition to this, the city of Colombo is regarded as the financial centre of the island and every year, millions of tourists come to this city for spending a holiday. All in all, Colombo is a vibrant city that offers a blend of cultural heritage (colonial buildings with ancient bits and pieces) with modern life surroundings.

## Things to see in Colombo

**National Museum of Colombo:** A few decades back, Sri Lanka has been modernized, but the entire civilization of this country has lasted here for millennia. Among these ancient civilizations, the most prominent is the National Museum of Colombo. This museum illustrates a diversified collection of ancient civilization as you will observe the ancient ruins of Sri Lankan history, artworks, and the remnants from the Anuradhapura Kingdom (dating back to the fourth century B.C.).

**Independence Memorial Hall:** In 1948, Sri Lanka got its independence from Britain and this is the place where this historic moment took place. Moreover, the huge stone-made building is enclosed by a serene garden. In front of the hall, there is a statue of Sri Lankas first ever president (The Father of the Nation). Additionally, this iconic hall is used for various religious events alongside yearly national day celebration. The hall is peaceful and crowd-less bring a sense of calmness to the visitors.

**Gangaramaya Buddhist Temple:** Sri Lanka has a long and illustrious history, which includes several transitions. But the only constant thing during these transitions is the practice of Buddhism. Now, the city of Colombo represents Buddhism in the best possible manner with the iconic Gangaramaya Buddhist Temple. This temple is home to the holy Bodhi tree, with loads of Buddha images of different sizes. This is why this temple is a must-see attraction for the tourists.

**Beira Lake:** The Beira Lake is one of the classic tourist attractions in the city of Colombo. It is colossal and when you exit from the Gangaramaya Temple, you will be tempted to have a rest alongside the shores of this wonder lake. Around the lake, various modernizations and shop fronts have taken place, but it still manages to remain peaceful. This is why tourists love to take a respite from the busy and hectic schedule in the Beira Lake.


## Things to do in Colombo

**Spot the magnificent whales:** Sri Lanka is renowned for many beautiful spectacles, and whales are one such spectacle that compels the tourists to say  Wow! When you are on a boat in the Sri Lankan waters, you can easily spot the magnificent sperm and blue whales. These whales will glide past your boat gracefully, and watching these whales is a thing of beauty and unravel to any attraction. You can spot them in Dondra Point, which is close to Galle, Hikkaduwa and Mirissa.

**Go for a fascinating train voyage:**A charming train ride with Sri Lankas timeless colonial trains would take you to the Golden Age of Travel. This railway line was created to transfer spices and tea from the hazy mountains to Colombos port. Besides, this is a historic railway line that goes through rugs of progressing tea plantations, hidden waterfalls, spice gardens, and ever smiling rail-side merchants. The locals would embrace you gracefully, making your trip more pleasant.

**Get lost while soaking in the beaches:** Colombo is home to various beaches, which can rival the exotic beaches of Europe and the Caribbean. All of these beaches are encircled by coconut palm fringed shorelines with turquoise waters and white dusty sands. Getting lost in these beaches would offer a fitting end to your trip in Colombo.

If you're looking forward to try some awesome delicious foods in the town, check this out top 6 restaurant in Colombo

## How is the weather in Colombo?

The climate of Colombo is a tropical monsoon one and ironically, it has fallen short of a tropical rainforest climate. Throughout the year, the climate of this city is fairly temperate. Additionally, the city experiences a reasonable change during the monsoon season (from May to August and October to January). At this time, there are significant rainfalls and the average rainfall in the city is around 2,400 millimeters a year.
Furthermore, the warmest month in Colombo is January and the coolest month is September. Moreover, the wettest month is May and the driest month is January.

## How to reach Colombo?

You can reach Colombo by the following options 

**By Bus:** Generally, buses are a good option to travel around Colombo. Buses are also the cheapest option to get around the city of Colombo. However, you will sometimes find a lot of crowds while travelling by bus. Usually, there are two types of buses by which you can reach Colombo. Additionally, there are government owned public buses as well as there are privately owned buses. Following is a list of the routes by which you can reach Colombo from different cities.

- A1 highway connects Colombo with Kandy.
- A2 highway connects Colombo with Galle.
- A3 highway connects Colombo with Negombo.
- A4 highway connects Colombo with Ratnapura.

**By Train:** Train is an important transportation option in Sri Lanka, and travelling by train is comfortable for many reasons. Usually, a train has different classes in which you can travel. 
These classes include 

- 1st-class sleeper
- 1st-class observation car
- 1st class air-conditioned seat car
- 2nd-class seats
- 3rd-class seats

You must book your seat in advance (probably within 10 days of departure) to avoid any kind of hassles. You can easily buy tickets from the station, or you can contact the railway authority for booking your reservation.

Finally, it can be said that Colombo is a special city that is diversified enough to afford elegant eateries, museums, temples, galleries, a serene atmosphere, and wildlife in one basket. When you are exploring this city, you will be surprised by the uniqueness and authenticity of Colombo. All in all, Colombo is the perfect city to start or finish your Sri Lankan adventures. Explore it with our Colombo travel guide.

For inquiries contact [Olanka Travels](link). Check out [6 days in the Sri Lanka](link) tour package where Colombo has been included.

data.title: Arugam Bay Travel Guide: The Complete Guide
data.short_description: Arugam Bay in Sri Lanka is regarded as an oasis of peace and tranquility. This is a small land with a population of only 3500 people.

content.content:
Arugam Bay in Sri Lanka is regarded as the oasis of peace and tranquillity. This is a small land with a population of only 3500 people. It is located on the Indian Ocean, which is in the dry zone of Sri Lankas southeast coast. In addition to this, Arugam Bay is situated 320 km due east of Colombo. Local people call Arugam  Ullai and this place is renowned worldwide for surfing and tourist attractions.

In fact, this place is one of the top ten best places for surfing. However, this moon-shaped curling soft land is much more than surfing. You can go on a lagoon tour or just enjoy watching the elephants. Also, you can opt to visit the cultural sites and there are plenty of wildlife retrospectives as well. So, lets take a tour to Arugam and unearth its wonders.

## Things to see in Arugam Bay

**Pottuvil Lagoon:** If you go two kilometres from Arugam Bay, you will see the beautiful inland called Pottuvil Lagoon. A picturesque lagoon tour in the scenic Pottuvil will be something extraordinary. When you paddle out into the lagoon, you will be amazed to see the eye-catching mangrove swamps. These swamps are just lively with birds chirping, and it is filled with lizards, elephants, and crocodiles. All of them would provide you a taste of the Sri Lanka wildlife of Arugam Bay.

**Panama:** Panama is the last inhabited village in Arugam Bay, which is located 12 km south. It goes before the Yala East National Park and Panama intersects inland with the lagoons of Arugam Bay. Now, Panama is blessed with endless beaches, wonderful lagoons, rock stones, and sand dunes. All of these sightseeing elements make Panama a captivating landscape. Panama is combined with two gigantic rocky projections known as  Crocodile Rock and Elephant Rock. The Crocodile Rock is famous for surfing spots and the Elephant Rock is popular for wild elephants.

**Okanda Sri Lanka:** The village of Okanda is 20 km south of Arugam Bay, and it is hugely popular for surfing spots. It is home to the admired shrine that is situated at the point in which God Skanda had landed on the island (the legend says). This shrine is the opening point of Paada Yaathra (Pilgrimage on Foot). Moreover, Okanda is the entry point of the Yala East National Park where the mangroves alongside the Kumana Reservoir and these places happen to be the breeding ground of aquatic birds.

**Yala East National Park Sri Lanka:** Yala East National Park in Sri Lanka is a twin sister of Yala West or Yala Ruhuna National Park. The main stumbling block between these national parks is the River Kumbukkan Oya and precisely, the river flows segregate both these sanctuaries. Now, Yala East is just as popular as the Yala West, and it is home to precious leopards and mammals. Plus, there is a great amount of elephant population, but the herds are smaller than the Yala West.

**Kumana Bird Sanctuary:** Kumana Bird Sanctuary is nationally and internationally recognized as an important wetland habitat for both local and migratory wading birds. Kumana Bird Sanctuary is hosted by a channel from the River Kumbukkan Oya. It is about 20 km into the Yala East National Park; you will observe the Kumana Reservoir. This reservoir is packed with mangrove trees, and it hosts a wide range of aquatic birds. Among these aquatic birds, the most seen are herons, egrets, storks, little cormorants, and Indian darters. You can also see one of the rare breed birds  Black-necked stork in this bird sanctuary.

## Things to do in Arugam Bay

**Surfing and Diving:** Arugam Bay is widely popular for surfing spots and this place is ranked among the top ten surfing hubs in the world. This place is renowned for some extraordinary waves that draw thousands of surfers from across the world. Usually, the mean height of these waves ranges from 1.5 to 2.5 metres. The perfect season for surfing in Arugam Bay is between May and November. At this time, the wind will be largely offshore for the first half of the day. There are several right-hand point breaks in Arugam Bay, and it is like this because of its geographic location alongside southerly swell direction.

Furthermore, the most famous three-point breaks are  The Point, Pottuvil Point and Crocodile Rock and they are the best points for surfing. Local people are just obsessed with surfing and are willing to guide you through to the unknown point breaks. Besides, Arugam Bay is much more than surfing because it is home to a wide array of tropical fishes and this place is considered to be a gorgeous snorkelling paradise. So, if you love diving, you can hire a boat and head towards the Basses Reefs. This is the best scuba diving site in the entire Arugam Bay.


**Experience the Wildlife:** Arugam Bay is filled with wildlife spectacles and some of the rarest of creatures live in Arugam Bay. Now, if you want to have some glimpses of wildlife in Arugam Bay such as  wild boar, deer, crocodiles, and colossal elephants, you should go out on tour in the dawn or sunset (this is the best time to catch the glimpses of wildlife). Also, if you head towards the southern part of Arugam, you will find the famous Yala National Park, which is one of the leading ecotourism destinations in Sri Lanka. This national park covers an approximate area of 1,300 square kilometres and boasts the highest bulk of leopards in the entire Asia. These creatures live peacefully with wild elephant, sloth bear, striped necked brown and ruddy mongoose, marsh mugger crocodile, sambar, wild boar, several civet species, and chital.

**Visit the Cultural Site  Magul Maha Viharaya:** When you are heading towards Lahugala National Park, you will come across Magul Maha Viharaya. It is a hidden pearl that has roots from the 2nd century B.C. The history and background information is not clear, but people cited that it was created by King Dathusena (he ruled the Anuradhapura Kingdom from 516AD to 526AD). This fact is proved right as all these events were claimed on the stone inscriptions (dates back to 14th century). Nevertheless, the legend says that this temple was made by King Kavantissain throughout the 2nd century B.C.

Additionally, this site covers an area over 10,000 acres, and it is a symbol of culture and history. It is beautifully portrayed with unusual architectural establishments along with vast lily ponds. Plus, the remnants of an ancient palace would Wow the tourists.

Also check our guide on the best hotels in [Arugam Bay.](link)

## How is the weather in Arugam Bay?

Since Arugam Bay is situated on the Indian Ocean in the dry zone of Sri Lankan South-East coast, Arugam Bay has its own weather. Compared to other islands in the country, this place experiences the least amount of rain. On top of that, surfers would enjoy surfing in the months of April and August as these are the best times for surfing with perfect waves. Generally, Arugam Bay has warm and tropical weather. In the months of November, December and January, the mean temperature in this place is between 28  30 degree Celsius. Additionally, the months of February, March, September, and October experience an average temperature of 30 -32 degree Celsius and lastly, the months of April, May, June, July, and August will provide you with a temperature of 32 -36 degree Celsius.

## How to reach Arugam Bay?

In order to reach Arugam Bay, you have to go through a significant amount of travelling. In addition to this fact, getting around Arugam Bay with a preferred choice of will be easy. The en route to Arugam Bay from the Katunayake International Airport or from the capital city of Colombo, the capital city, contains several means of transportation. With that being said, you can opt to hire a car, van, taxi or any forms of vehicles. However, it will also depend on your budget. Besides, the public transportation facilities such as  train, air-conditioned buses are always available for taking you to Arugam Bay.

Finally, Arugam Bay is revered in Sri Lanka and in the world because there are only a few places similar to Arugam Bay. This tiny piece of land will set you free with unlimited freedom. You will find plenty of pleasure in the landscapes and the attractions. All in all, it is a magical place that will make you feel heavenly and explore it with our Arugam Bay travel guide.

For inquiries contact [Olanka Travels](link). Check our Sri Lanka itinerary for 6 days to include Arugam Bay.

data.title: Dambulla Travel Guide: The Complete Guide
data.short_description: Dambulla is a large city that is located in the Matale District, Central Province of Sri Lanka. The city resides 148 km north-east of Colombo and 72 km north of Kandy. Dambulla belongs to the Cultural Triangle, which was declared by UNESCO, and it happens to be on the main road from Sigiriya to Kandy. Also, it is 19 km away from Sigiriya.

content.content: Dambulla is a large city that is located in the Matale District, Central Province of Sri Lanka. The city resides 148 km north-east of Colombo and 72 km north of Kandy. Dambulla belongs to the Cultural Triangle, which was declared by UNESCO, and it happens to be on the main road from Sigiriya to Kandy. Also, it is 19 km away from Sigiriya. Dambulla is surrounded by more than 80 caves, and some of these caves are frequently used by the monks as a meditation place.

Furthermore, the main attraction of this city is the five caves that comprises of statues and several paintings. These caves were founded by King Valagamba by the 1st century B.C. However, over the years, many changes and renovations have been made to these caves. Besides, Dambulla is situated at a key intersection point and consequently, that is the centre of vegetable distribution in the entire country. Above all, Dambulla is a unique city with lots of historical interests.


## Things to See in Dambulla 

**Dambulla Rock Temple:** Dambulla is blessed with more than 80 caves and the central attraction of this city is the Dambulla Rock Temple. This temple includes five cave temples and they have roots to the first century B.C Additionally, this temple is one of the UNESCO world heritage sites and it is the biggest and best-preserved cave temple complex of Sri Lanka as well. The towers in the cave are 160 m long and are over the encircling plains. Here, you will see paintings and statues of Lord Buddha and his life. There are 153 Buddha statues in total along with three statues of Sri Lankan kings and four statues of god and goddess. All of these statues and paintings are just amazing and wonderful. Every year, tourists from around the world visit the Dambulla Rock Temple just to experience these astonishing creations.

**Rose Quartz Mountain:** The Rose Quartz Mountain is approximately 500 million years old and it is a mountain range. This is one of the top attractions of Dambulla. You will a lot of white rose alongside violet color quartz in the Rose Quartz Mountain. If you start a trek to reach this highest Mountain range in the entire South Asia, you will be feeling a sense of satisfaction. The reason for this is that it will present you a stunning view of the adjoining countryside for miles. Though the mountain is made of rose quartz, you cant recognize easily.

**Iron Wood Forest:** The Iron Wood Forest was considered to be a human sanctuary and many believe that it was made by King Dappula, the 10th Century AD ruler. This is forest is recognized as Jathika Namal Uyana and it will offer you a captivating trek through the deep jungle. This jungle is covered by the Sri Lankan national tree, the Naa. Plus, this forest has significant value to ecologists since it carries an ecological importance the country.

## Things to do in Dambulla

**Visit the Golden Temple Buddhist Museum:** The Golden Temple Buddhist Museum is standing at the foot of the golden Buddha statue. At the entrance point of the museum, you will see a massive lion-like beast. The museum is quite big. However, it has a few numbers of exhibits except some tedious pieces of the cave temple paintings. But you will definitely enjoy while visiting this museum as it marks the historical evidence of Buddha for the visitors.

**Bird and Monkey Watching:** While staying in Dambulla, you can get fun while watching birds and monkeys. Generally, the city is famous for its bird watching tours. Also, there are lots of monkeys, which are quite funny given that they tend to show hilarious acts. Other than this, the top bird watching tours in Dambulla are hosted in the Rose Quartz Mountain area as well as in Iron Wood Forest.

**Shop in Dambulla:** Dambulla boasts comprehensive and modernized markets and they make the city more appealing to the tourists. The city has become the commercial hub of Sri Lankas North Province. When you stroll on the streets, you will get to see several shops displaying a puzzling array of agricultural equipment, bicycles by the dozen, household utensils, etc. These markets best represent the local culture of Dambulla.

## How is the weather of Dambulla?

Dambulla has classic tropical weather with less rainfall in the summer season. The average temperature of Dambulla is 26.8  and the average rainfall is 1557 mm in each year. Generally, the months of January, February, March, April, and May feature a pleasant average temperature. Usually, the heavy rainfall is seen in the months June, July, August, September, October, November, and December. On an average scale, the warmest month of Dambulla is April and the coolest month is August. On the other hand, the driest month of Dambulla is March and the wettest month is October.

## How to reach Dambulla?

You can reach Dambulla by the following options 

**By Air:** There are flights available up to Bandaranaike International Airport and Katunayaka airport where you can easily reach Dambulla through a bus or hired car.

**By Water:** Sri Lanka has three deep-water ports and they are situated at Galle, Colombo and Trincomalee. After reaching these ports, you can hire a bus or taxi to reach Dambulla.

**By Train:** Dambulla is 45 km away from Gal Oya junction on the eastern railway line. It is also away from Matale on the Main Line with a same distance. After reaching any of these railway lines, you can easily reach Dambulla by car or bus.

To finish off, Dambulla is an attractive proposition for several tourists because it is unique and is the commercial hub of the country. With ancient cave temples, the city becomes more alluring as they will take the tourists to the era of Buddha. When you are traveling to Dambulla, you should remember that this place is sacred as well. So, dont miss a bit of this one-of-a-kind city and enjoy your trip to the fullest with our Dambulla travel guide.

For inquires contact [Olanka Travels](https://www.olankatravels.com/). Check our[ 6 day Sri Lanka tour package](https://www.olankatravels.com/tour-packages/sri-lanka-tours/6-days-tour-package/) to include Dambulla.

data.title: The Most Romantic Honeymoon Destinations in Sri Lanka
data.short_description: Finding the best honeymoon locations in Sri Lanka for your romantic getaway is a lot of work. Whether you are two thrill-seekers who are looking for a serene getaway for your honeymoon or romantic destination to spend your next big anniversary, Sri Lanka offers many options just for you.

content.content:
Finding the best honeymoon locations in Sri Lanka for your romantic getaway is a lot of work. Whether you are two thrill-seekers who are looking for a serene getaway for your honeymoon or romantic destination to spend your next big anniversary, Sri Lanka offers many options just for you. From tranquil country sides, hiking trails with a stupendous view in the hillside to secluded crystal clear beaches, heres a list of romantic honeymoon destinations in Sri Lanka for all the unique duos out there.

## Bentota: For Your Sea-side Adventures

If your vision for your Sri Lanka honeymoon is an ultimate beach getaway, you cant go wrong with Bentata, a busy beach town that offers the perfect mix of romance, luxury, serenity, and adventure. From candlelight dinners by the beach, secluded boat rides to adventurous water sports such as water skiing, sea kayaking and canoeing, Bentota offers one of the best Sri Lankan honeymoon experiences one can think of. Animal lovers could also get to share some love with the beautiful sea turtles at the Sea Turtle Protection Association.

## Nuwara-Eliya: The Intimate Hillside

Cuddle up with your loved ones as you escape the city side heat. [Honeymoon locations in Sri Lanka](https://www.olankatravels.com/tours/sri-lanka/sri-lanka-tour-itinerary-12-days/) dont get as chilly and cosy as in Nuwara Eliya. Saddle up for some horse rides, lie down on the green next to the icy cold Gregory Lake and explore the lush green Ceylon tea plantations stretching across the landscape. At the end of the day, cosy up by the fireplace of a hillside colonial style bungalow with the finest cup of Ceylon tea.

![nuwara-eliya-sri-lanka-best-romantic-destinations-in-sri-lanka-by-olanka-travels-768x403.webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/nuwara_eliya_sri_lanka_best_romantic_destinations_in_sri_lanka_by_olanka_travels_768x403_21b2f20de3.webp)

## Yala: Luxury Forest Camping and Safaris

If you or your partner love wildlife, a safari adventure must make it to your Sri Lanka honeymoon package itinerary. Hop onto a unique safari experience at the most famous national park in Sri Lanka, Yala. Get up close and personal with the wildlife better than ever, even during the night! Look over the entire forest through the comfort of your own luxury treehouse or camp. Enjoy bird watching and leopard spotting together. Scout a few other national parks in the vicinity of Yala, and let your wild side resonate around you.

## Mirissa: The Whale Watching Date

Having a date on the remote and tropical Mirissa beach with some water sports, dolphin and whale watching is quite a merrymaking. With plenty of places to feast on and glamorous places to spend the night together, Mirissa serves as a great destination to add to any Sri Lankan honeymoon packages to turn things up a notch.

## Kandy: The Cultural Expedition

Tune into your spiritual cravings with a cultural pilgrimage to Kandy. Being the last of the royal cities in Sri Lanka, the mist-filled city on the hills has plenty of historic artefacts and cultural sights to offer apart from other tourist hotspots. Pay a visit to the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic together, pamper your lover with a shopping spree at the Kandy City Center and end the day with a romantic walk around the Kandy Lake.

![Kandy-srilanka-best-and-romantic-honeymoon-destinations-in-sri-lanka-by-olanka-travels-2-768x403.webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/Kandy_srilanka_best_and_romantic_honeymoon_destinations_in_sri_lanka_by_olanka_travels_2_768x403_6c96645abf.webp)

## Hikkaduwa: Classy Coastal Getaway

Another famous honeymoon location in Sri Lanka is Hikkaduwa. Enjoy a luxurious beachside villa and spend a relaxing time together. Try some snorkelling and surfing at the beach that is home to gorgeous sea turtles. You could also visit the Coral Sanctuary, Hikkaduwa Turtle Hatchery, the numerous Museums, nearby temples and attractions.

## Sigiriya: History and the Priceless View

Conquer the fear of heights together and climb the Lion Fortress. Acres of gardens, historic pools and of course the famous Lion Rock. Saunter with your beloved hand-in-hand and immerse yourself in the natural and famed beauty that lies around you. Get lost gazing at the breathtaking view that lies at the top, celebrating your Sigiriya adventure together.

![sri-lanka-honeymoon-by-olanka-travels-768x403.webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/sri_lanka_honeymoon_by_olanka_travels_768x403_e10ca698f7.webp)

## Polonnaruwa: Cycle through the Ancient City

Polonnaruwa is a city filled with ancient ruins, museums, and shrines that you could cycle around with your partner! If you happen to be a pair of history lovers, then this is one of the best honeymoon locations in Sri Lanka that you can imagine. Explore it all, from the Royal Palace to the Sacred Quadrangle.

## Tangalle Beach: A Beach to Yourself

With Tangalle Beach, you dont have to worry about finding the ideal coves and bays all to yourself. Dawdle alongside the empty beaches and get the best Sri Lankan honeymoon experiences there is to offer from the luxury hotels in the vicinity. If you are looking for a private and uncrowded beach for an intimate beach escape, Tangalle is for you.

![tangalle-beach-sri-lanka-best-honeymoon-destination-by-olanka-travels-2-768x403.webp](https://olanka-strapi-uat-s3.s3.amazonaws.com/tangalle_beach_sri_lanka_best_honeymoon_destination_by_olanka_travels_2_768x403_199cb6da6d.webp)

## Galle  The Colonial Vibe

City of Galle is filled with sights and monuments that remind the colonial era of the island. Awaken the inner foodies with the scrumptious variety of goodies around town and spend the evening seated beside the Galle Fort facing the horizon enjoying the strong coastal breeze.

There are many more beautiful places that couldnt make our list of the [top honeymoon locations in Sri Lanka](https://www.olankatravels.com/tours/sri-lanka/sri-lanka-tour-itinerary-12-days/). Get in touch with us to find the best Sri Lanka honeymoon destinations to create the ideal Sri Lanka Honeymoon package for you and your partner.

faq.name: Is a passport and visa required?
faq.description: Passports are necessary for visitors from outside the Maldives. Tourists staying for less than 30 days in the Maldives will be awarded a free visa on arrival.

faq.name: When is the best time to go to the Maldives?
faq.description: The Maldives are an outstanding tropical adventure destination with spectacular weather and gorgeous island landscapes. The Maldives have mild temperatures all year and the best weather from November to February. March through April is also an excellent time to come, particularly for surfers. The wet season lasts from May until October.

faq.name: How do I navigate to the resort from the airport?
faq.description: Getting about the Maldives is simple. You can get to your Maldives resort by speedboat or seaplane from Mal.

faq.name: What is the official language of the Maldives?
faq.description: Maldivian (Dhivehi) is the official language of the Maldives.

faq.name: Is English widely spoken in the Maldives?
faq.description: English is widely spoken across the country, particularly in resort areas and in the capital, Male.

faq.name: In the Maldives, what currency is used?
faq.description: The Maldivian rufiyaa is the official currency of the Maldives, but the Euro and US dollar are also commonly accepted.

faq.name: Is there an ATM and can I use my credit card?
faq.description: ATMs can be found throughout Mal, as well as at the international airport. ATMs, on the other hand, are few, if not non-existent, on several tourist islands. All purchases at your resort can be made with your credit card

faq.name: Is there anything specific I should wear or bring?
faq.description: It is recommended that you carry some presentable clothing if you are staying in Mal or the other inhabited islands. You can wear your regular vacation clothing after you arrive at your resort. It's a good idea to bring mosquito spray and sunscreen with you. These things are also available in the Maldives.  A dry bag, as well as a waterproof camera, are wonderful ideas for waterproofing your valuables on snorkeling adventures.

faq.name: Can I use my standard plugs in the Maldives?
faq.description: The Maldives uses a variety of plug sockets, including types C/D/G/J/K/L, with a standard voltage of 230 V and a frequency of 50Hz. To make life easier, we recommend bringing a  multi-purpose international adaptor.

faq.name: Can I bring alcohol?
faq.description: Carrying alcohol into the Maldives is forbidden. Resorts have unique licenses to serve certain beverages, and the majority of resorts offer top brands from throughout the world.

faq.name: Will the resort include vegetarian food options?
faq.description: Most resorts have a large selection of vegetarian dishes on their menus. There is something for everyone in the Maldives!

faq.name: Is tipping common in the Maldives?
faq.description: Tipping is not widely practiced in the Maldives. It is not permitted at the airport. Hotels and restaurants discourage it because most already add a 10% service charge to your bill. You may, however, tip at your discretion.

faq.name: Is the Maldives just for honeymooners?
faq.description: Simply put, no! The Maldives is ideal for thrill seekers eager for an action-packed experience, as well as those who enjoy the water or simply want to relax. There are kid-friendly resorts as well as adults-only resorts with a range of activities to keep you entertained.

faq.name: How are the Maldives' medical facilities?
faq.description: Most resorts provide an on-site doctor for emergency medical care. If the resort does not have one, a nearby island with medical services will be available. In general, the Maldives has a huge government hospital called Indira Gandhi Memorial Hospital, a private hospital called ADK Hospital in Male', the capital city, and an emergency hospital called Tree Top Hospital in Hulhumale'.

faq.name: Do I need a visa to visit Vietnam?
faq.description: The Vietnamese Immigration Department issues E-visas to foreigners through an online application process

faq.name: What is the best time to visit Vietnam?
faq.description: The best season to visit Vietnam is between February and April, as well as August and October, when rainfall is lower and temperatures are more mild.

faq.name: What language is spoken in Vietnam?
faq.description: Vietnamese is the official language of Vietnam.

faq.name: Is English spoken across Vietnam?
faq.description: Many Vietnamese do not speak English. However, in tourist locations, English will be understood in hotels and restaurants.

faq.name: What currency is used in Vietnam?
faq.description: The Vietnamese dong is the currency used throughout Vietnam. Many hotels, restaurants, and tourist sites accept MasterCard and Visa. Most large cities have ATMs.

faq.name: Are credit cards generally accepted in Vietnam?
faq.description: In Vietnam, major credit cards are generally accepted by large shops, hotels, and restaurants. They may not, however, be accepted by smaller merchants such as small eateries, market stalls, or in distant towns and villages.

faq.name: How does tipping work in Vietnam?
faq.description: Although tipping is not mandatory in Vietnam, it is customary and greatly appreciated. While we give our guides and drivers a fair wage, tips still account for a sizable amount of the income of Vietnamese working in tourism. It is absolutely up to you how much you desire to tip.

faq.name: Can I use my cell phone in Vietnam?
faq.description: Yes, you will be able to use your mobile phone in most urban areas of Vietnam, while network coverage may be limited in isolated and hilly locations.

faq.name: What modes of transportation are available in Vietnam?
faq.description: In Vietnam, there are numerous ways to move around. Domestic flights inside the country can provide rapid and convenient travel between the country's north and south. To explore smaller towns or villages, trains or hired drivers are also available. Bicycle rentals are also available for getting about the city and town.

faq.name: Is Vietnam a good choice for families?
faq.description: In Vietnam, there are numerous activities and locations to visit that the entire family may enjoy! Some of these include exploring Ho Chi Minh City, traveling through the Cu Chi Tunnels, and cruising through the Mekong Delta's floating markets of Cai Rang and Cai Be.

faq.name: What are the most common illnesses encountered by visitors to Vietnam?
faq.description: Most likely, you'll come home with a typical cold or some mild stomach problems. Heat-related problems such as heatstroke and dehydration can be a problem during the summer. Maintain hydration and apply sunscreen as needed.

faq.name: Is there a dress code for specific Vietnam attractions?
faq.description: When visiting religious sites, the countryside, and the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, dress modestly and cover your shoulders and knees. When visiting a temple or pagoda, remember to remove your hat.

faq.name: Is vegetarian cuisine easily available in Vietnam?
faq.description: Vietnam is one of the world's most vegetarian-friendly countries. Vegan foods can be more difficult to find (due to the Vietnamese fondness of fish sauce), although sweets are generally vegan by default.

faq.name: Can I drink the water from the tap in Vietnam?
faq.description: In general, drinking tap water is not advised in Vietnam. It was suggested that you drink from a bottle.

faq.name: Is it safe to visit Vietnam?
faq.description: In many ways, Vietnam is a very safe place to visit. However, as with anywhere else in the globe, it is critical to stay alert of your surroundings and apply common sense, especially in congested areas and when using public transportation.

faq.name: Is Vietnam a welcoming place for LGBTQI people?
faq.description: The LGBQTI community is steadily gaining respect in Vietnam, with gay pride parades becoming more common and same-sex marriage laws being lifted in 2015. Having said that, Vietnam is still a conservative culture in which many people hide their sexuality from their families. Gay-friendly pubs and events may be found in both Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi. It is widely advised that homosexual and straight couples avoid public displays of affection.

faq.name: When is the best time of year to visit Indonesia?
faq.description: Between May through September, when the weather is dry and bright, is the greatest time to visit Indonesia.

faq.name: In Indonesia, what language is spoken?
faq.description: Indonesian, a standardized variant of Malay, is the country's official language.

faq.name: Is English widely spoken in Indonesia?
faq.description: The majority of Indonesians will learn English as a second language. However, it should not be expected that everyone speaks English.

faq.name: Why Should I go to Indonesia?
faq.description: Except for Bali, Indonesia is largely off the tourist radar, but the country is worth visiting. Indonesia is so huge, alive, and dynamic that exploring all of the islands, observing the distinct customs and practices, and visiting thousands of spectacular natural tourist attractions may take years. Traveling through Indonesia is never boring because there are always new sites to discover and new people to meet. When everything is finished, you will get the impression that they have traveled across a whole continent.

faq.name: Is Indonesia safe?
faq.description: Indonesia is a generally safe country, both in the countryside and in urban areas. Travelers should always be mindful of their surroundings and exercise common sense when venturing out at night, but crime rates in general, particularly against visitors, are relatively low. Pickpockets are the most commonly cited problem when visiting crowded marketplaces or retail centers.

faq.name: In Indonesia, what currency is used?
faq.description: The Indonesian rupiah is the currency used across the country. Most vendors in high-traffic locations take Mastercard or Visa. ATMs may be located in the majority of Indonesian cities.

faq.name: In Indonesia, can I use my credit card?
faq.description: Bring your credit cards, but keep in mind that certain destinations still prefer cash as a form of payment. If you want to reserve accommodations, inquire ahead of time whether credit cards are accepted at your preferred hotels. VISA and MasterCard are widely accepted in major cities. However, it is advisable to keep some cash on hand in addition to your credit cards for convenience.

faq.name: Is there public transit in Indonesia?
faq.description: The minibus, which is utilized for local transportation across towns and cities, is Indonesia's principal mode of transportation within the country.

faq.name: Is Indonesia suitable for families?
faq.description: Indonesia has things for the entire family to enjoy! Swimming and snorkeling at beaches, the Sacred Monkey Forest Sanctuary in Ubud, and the Turtle Conservation and Education Centre in Denpasar are among them.

faq.name: What types of meals can I find in Indonesia?
faq.description: There are several foreign food options in the capital cities. If you want to try something new, look for local dishes, which can be found anywhere from street food vendors to five-star hotels.

faq.name: Is it safe to drink the water?
faq.description: In general, tap water in Indonesia is NOT safe to drink. Bottled water is widely available at tourist attractions, hotels, and restaurants, and hot water (boiled to make it safe to drink) or hot tea is usually served with a meal.

faq.name: What kind of electrical plugs should I have on hand?
faq.description: Bring an electrical adapter with you; Indonesian plugs are two-pin round plugs (Type C & F) with a voltage of 220 V 50 Hz.

faq.name: What aspects of Indonesian culture should I consider?
faq.description:
Because Indonesia is a deeply religious country, it is customary to cover your shoulders and wear shorts/trousers or a skirt that falls below the knee. You can wear a swimsuit on the beaches, but be aware of how others may feel and always cover up while entering beachfront eateries and cafs.
Things are a little more relaxed in Bali and the Gili Islands, but it is still crucial to respect the feelings of the locals.

faq.name: What language is spoken in Dubai?
faq.description: The official language of Dubai is Arabic, but there are other dialects spoken around the city. Standard Arabic, the modernized language, is used in all legal, administrative, and government texts, as well as literature and periodicals.

faq.name: Do they speak English?
faq.description: In Dubai, English is the most widely spoken language. With a large number of expats, the majority of whom speak English as a native or second language, you'll have no trouble getting around. Hindi, Urdu, and Tagalog are also widely spoken here.

faq.name: What can I do in Dubai?
faq.description: Dubai is a diversified location that caters to people of all ages and interests. Tourists may spend their days resting by the water, while adventurers can explore the spectacular desert environment and discover the local animals. The emirate also offers a rich culture, as well as a variety of entertainment alternatives, theme parks, and spa experiences. Dubai is famous for its landmarks such as the Burj Khalifa, the Burj Al Arab, and the Palm Jumeirah.

faq.name: What is the official currency of Dubai? Do I need to bring credit cards?
faq.description: Dubai's currency is the Arab Emirate Dirham. There are numerous ATMs located across the city where you can withdraw money. In addition, most retail centers, hotels, and restaurants accept all major international debit and credit cards.

faq.name: What can you get in Dubai for AED 1?
faq.description: Dubai is not as pricey as it appears. There are numerous attractions that are both inexpensive and enjoyable. The iconic abra trip across Dubai Creek, for example, costs only AED 1. If you want to go a step further, you can get some wonderful choco dates, Chips Oman crackers, or a hot cup of traditional karak chai, an aromatic spiced tea with milk, from a streetside vendor cafe.

faq.name: Is it possible to find vegetarian food in Dubai?
faq.description: Dubai food offers a wide range of vegetarian delicacies that will leave you wanting more. Vegetarian options abound, ranging from street-side shacks to restaurants.

faq.name: Is it safe to drink tap water in Dubai?
faq.description: In general, yes, you can drink tap water in Dubai.

faq.name: Can I consume alcohol in Dubai?
faq.description: Yes, alcohol is sold in Dubai. Tourists and citizens over the age of 21 can consume alcohol in Dubai at licensed premises such as hotels and restaurants, as well as designated lounges.

faq.name: Is it acceptable to wear shorts in Dubai?
faq.description: Yes, both men and women are permitted to wear shorts in Dubai. Tourists and expats are politely asked to respect local customs by covering their legs below the knee in enclosed public areas such as malls. Wear conservative clothes that covers your legs and shoulders if you are visiting a religious location.

faq.name: Can I swim in Dubai's sea?
faq.description: In Dubai, you can swim in the water. The waters are usually calm, and lifeguards are stationed at all beaches to ensure that health and safety regulations are observed.

faq.name: What should I carry with me to Dubai?
faq.description: As with any sunny vacation destination, please bring your summer clothes, swimwear, and flip-flops. If you want to experience Dubai's nightlife, smarter clothing is recommended.

faq.name: Is Dubai secure?
faq.description: Dubai is extremely safe; in fact, the global database Numbeo ranked it one of the safest cities to visit in 2023. Strict rules protect everyone, so you can enjoy a stress-free and enjoyable family holiday in the city at any time of year.

faq.name: Is it safe to go out in Dubai at night?
faq.description: It is risk-free. In 2021, Gallup's Global Law and Order report declared the UAE the safest country in the world to walk around at night, with 95% of inhabitants reporting feeling safe. Nonetheless, it's always a good idea to stay cautious by staying in more visited regions and following a well-defined path.

faq.name: Is a visa/passport required?
faq.description: A passport valid for at least six months is required for travel to Cambodia. Most nationalities require a visa.

faq.name: Why should I visit Cambodia?
faq.description:
There are numerous reasons why Cambodia attracts so many visitors, including spectacular sights, rich culture, intriguing history, and the most wonderful and welcoming people.
Angkor Wat, the world's largest religious structure, is especially noteworthy. Every year, millions of tourists visit this temple.

faq.name: What is the official language of Cambodia?
faq.description: The official language of Cambodia is Khmer, which is spoken by around 90 percent of the people.

faq.name: Is English widely spoken in Cambodia?
faq.description: Aside from hospitality and tourism workers, few people will be fluent in English.

faq.name: In Cambodia, what currency is used?
faq.description: The official currency is the Cambodian riel. USD, on the other hand, is widely accepted and occasionally preferred. ATMs are available in all major cities.

faq.name: Is drinking tap water safe?
faq.description: Water quality varies by region in Cambodia, and we do not recommend drinking it. It is recommended to drink filtered water, which is available at hotels and restaurants.

faq.name: What is the best time to visit Cambodia?
faq.description: The country is pleasant all year, but the cool season, which runs from November to February, is regarded the greatest time to visit due to the temperate weather. It is more hotter from March through May, yet it is still a nice time to travel. June to October is the wet season.

faq.name: Is Cambodia suitable for families?
faq.description: Cambodia is a family-friendly vacation, although it is oriented toward active families. Visit the Angkor Archaeological Park by bicycle, enjoy a boat ride on Tonle Sap Lake, see the Cambodian Pare Circus, or escape to a beach resort for some water activities.

faq.name: How accepting is Cambodia of LGBTQ visitors and families?
faq.description: Cambodia is quite accommodating to LGBTQ visitors. Although homosexuality is legal in Cambodia, gay marriage is not recognized. However, because the country is conservative, public demonstrations of affection, regardless of sexual orientation, are frowned upon.

faq.name: Is an electricity converter/adapter required?
faq.description: Cambodia uses 230V, 50Hz AC electricity with A / C / G plugs. It is advised to bring a converter.

faq.name: What about the food?
faq.description: The majority of Khmer recipes are served with rice. Amok fish is the most popular dish; it's similar to curry but tastier, especially with Mekong River fish. The deep-fried tarantula is Cambodia's most popular dish. The majority of Cambodian tourists do this.

faq.name: What should I bring with me on a trip to Cambodia?
faq.description:
When visiting Cambodia, it is best to dress modestly, especially when visiting religious sites like the Angkor Wat temple complex - tops that cover your shoulders and skirts or pants that cover your knees are required. Otherwise, tourists should dress cool and comfortable, but be conscious of local customs and avoid exposing too much skin if they aren't on the beach.

A waterproof jacket is important, especially during the rainy season, and bringing a sarong can be handy as a towel, curtain, picnic blanket, or even temple cover-up.

faq.name: Is it safe to visit Cambodia?
faq.description: Cambodia is known as a highly safe place to visit. As in any country, it is always best to be aware of your surroundings and belongings. Keep big sums of cash out of sight and divide your cards and cash among multiple locations.

faq.name: How does tipping work in Cambodia?
faq.description: Tipping is not common in Cambodia. However, because most people's earnings are so low, tips are clearly appreciated. Tipping is becoming more popular among Cambodians working in the tourism business. Local guides and drivers' salaries are frequently determined in part by the fact that they also get tips. A tip of 5% to 10% of the entire bill is normal.
